content.rendered: Another fascinating, historical analysis of a great Early Bruce song. Going from Lincoln Center to Kent State, witnessing the band’s development.was inspirational. Ken, thanks again! I look forward to your daily posts.
Thanks for sharing…I never knew this existed!
Ken – You could use Arty “Supposed to Be” in this “Spare Parts” series…
I believe so, he typically did.
is Bruce playing the lead guitar on the break?
That’s the version I remember best! Beach Boys!
…and let’s not forget the Beach Boys great 1965 cover with Dennis singing lead. MS
Thank you Ken for doing this monumental task! It is much appreciated.
Love this wonderful post, & congrats on two years, Ken!! You’re so welcome, but really, we fans are truly thankful for you!! Always enjoy, nice to see, & all the best to you!! 😍
Ken Thanks so much for this incredible blog!!
Thanks to all of you! It’s so nice to hear when you like something you’ve read. 🙂
Thank YOU, Barbie, for reading and for taking the time to send me a note!

I have been a devoted fan of The Boss since the 70’s. I danced every Sunday night at the Stone Pony. In my career as a Bond Trader in nyc I was so proud to know that Bruce was helping victims of 911 and donated all proceeds from the Rising to 911. Thank-you so much!!

Hey KEN – I just want to thank you for all the information you provided about Bruce And the band ! I have learned so much from reading your posts – what I like most is the in-depth research that you do that makes reading meaningful – Thank you very much Ken – Happy New Year – Barbie
Thanks Ken! Very interesting. Keep ‘em coming.
Thank you, Suzanne! Please do share—I can publish many months in advance, so feel free to send your memories whenever you like. 🙂

You do a FANTASTIC job Ken! I love every post! I do have some personal stories with Bruce and I wish I would have written you last fall with my 1978 up front and personal ones. But I didn’t do it. Maybe next year.

Even with a pretty full mailbox (emptied unopened emails are numerous) these get opened without fail. It’s pretty obvious it’s a labor of love but thanks for sharing with all of us Bruce fans ‘out there’…Happy New Year!
A BIG Thank You, , Too .

Ken – I am relatively new to this blog…5 months or so, but it is the first 2 emails I look for in the morning. You have entertained, educated and inspired me with your insight, knowledge and consistency. Here’s to you and the blog! Both are very much appreciated!
first saw him at the Mosque venue in Richmond, Va in early 1974 and have been a life long super fan. i look forward to your emails each day to listen and learn more
Thank you!!!
I think he could possibly be saying Cassidy, Cassidy or even Cassie, Cassie….I mean why not, considering Bruce’s history of using female names in his songs.
I hear it both ways now…the power of suggestion!
Possible! I thought I heard “castle” too, at first, but I hear an extra syllable that makes me think Andy is right when he suggests “dance alone”
Second verse opening line sounds like: “In our castle, little castle, late night on the hour . . . .”
Hey, I think you’re right, Andy! Great ears—I’ll update and give you credit.
Perhaps “dance” instead of “cast,” giving “dance alone”…to me would make since with a title like “The Ballad.”

Ken, Fine review of Bob’s “Blowin’ In The Wind”: “…Dylan captures the frustrations of a society striving to follow their better angels but finding it increasingly difficult to do so.” Wow. Enjoyed both of Bruce’s versions and let’s not forget Bruce’s interpretation of “The Times They Are-A Changin'” for Bob at The Kennedy Center Honors. Go, Bob, Go Bruce! MS

that would be something to hear.. Thank you for sharing this video, Ken. It really shows Bruce’ modesty in presenting these great artists’ songs at such a momentous gathering, but also that he is able to bring ALL of his tremendous musicianship to lead people in a direction of caring for one another. cudos to Bruce Springsteen.

I loved this!!! So funny and clever, in a complimentary way. Well done Xander and Gil. You’ve put a smile on the dial of many Bruce fans, I’m sure. I hope Bruce sees and enjoys your performance too.. Sending you sunshine Christmas wishes from Cape Town, RSA.

thank you, Ken
I appreciate Bruce’ Earth embrace from early times of Flower Power
Sandy
A1 on the jukebox at Sleepy Joe’s Cafe
It is a great cover…the 2 voices intertwine with different interpretations and breathing…beautifully done.
I now love them!
Mavericks, never heard of them but I know love them!!!!
I think you’re right with regard to the “modern” version, Paul, but if it’s there in the original, it’s very tentative and tenuous.
Hi Ken, love the song analysis as always but feel rather than nihilistic the song shows acceptance as Bruce is no longer fighting the urge to challenge his friendships.

I will never, ever, ever understand why Bruce gave this song away. “All I Need” is one of my very favorite unfinished Bruce bootleg songs that I have. I didn’t even realize he finished it and gave it away to Bonds until about 6 months ago! I was crushed. Yes, this song belonged on The River. Would be killer live….oh well.
Wow! I’m super envious, haven’t even seen it once.
Wow considering only 5 times I’ve been extremely fortunate to have seen 3 of those times. 😎😎
Fantastic. Played very similar to the ONLY way it should be, from his greatest solo performance. That version is so intense and mesmerizing. Great work!
Very cool
It’s fantastic, Jake!
Thanks very much. It’s a great song, and I’m really happy to know you liked my try at it. I appreciate it.
I always loved Garland, seeing the two together is heaven, thanks.

Bruce says Western Stars is his philosophy, as he’s developed it to this point. This theme is developed to a high point in this album, don’t you think?
Mark, I find that song quite conclusive!! as always, marvellous work, Ken
“Lord, bless you, George”, indeed!
Ken, Great pick-up. George’s singing is just lovely. Thanks for finding and sharing.
So, an open-end conclusion as in “Tuscon Train”. Mark

This is easily a top 10 song for me in Bruce’s canon. It is beautifully sad to me. I think of Western Stars when I hear it now and wonder how Loose Change would fair in that type of arrangement…Thanks for the post!
beyond lovely. Gives us some insight into Bruce’ love for this woman. Thanks, Ken
That’s awesome. I didn’t know that, thanks for sharing.

“J” from JEMS had dinner in the T. Dome restaurant, which was on the upper west side which had a view looking down inside the Dome. “J” simply opened the class window next to his table and put his Nakamichi mics on the ledge and recorded the soundcheck into his D6. The legend, “J” captured it for all of us. M
Ha! Now I can’t stop singing “bus stop” to the tune of “chicken lips.” Thanks for that! 😂
Or did he chose it because it (somewhat) rhymes with “Wizard imps and sweat sock pimps, interstellar mongrel nymphs”
Ken wrote a great essay again about a soulful song by Bruce. My favourite version of Back In Your Arms was performed in New Jersey at Continental Airlines Arena on the summer night of August 4, 1999.

This is a great piece Ken. I was lucky enough to see it in Dublin in 2016. At one point the camera focussed on a woman in floods of tears which caused the audience to react. Bruce couldn’t see it and mistook the reaction for laughter. It was an extraordinary performance that had even Max clapping at the end.
I was at that show. Great night as always!
loved it great song i remember from my school days [ re released ]
Never heard a cover of The Monster Mash before,just shows how versatile Bruce and the band are. Thankyou
Ooh, that’s a tough comparison. I love them both.

One of his best and most beautiful songs.
Similar , but better, than Moonlight hotel
Ken, I’ve always wondered and been confused as to the chronology in reverse of Matamoros Banks. Thanks for your insightful observations I now “got it”. Mark Stricherz
Thanks, Mark!

Ken, Following the observation that the ’83 “Brothers'” concluding stanza, “not to hard to imagine.. the brothers…under the bridges have been sent off to fight in distant lands”, it appears this was the segue into the ’95 “Brothers”. Love your work. MS
I updated the article, thanks!
Ah, thanks, Philip—that’s the connection I should have but didn’t make!
Red shirt=freshman=2-S draft deferment, which the 1-A brothers wouldn’t have had.
Thanks 😊
The 455 was a GM big block V-8, late 60s/early 70s – https://www.liveabout.com/gm-455-cubic-inch-big-bloc-726346
I think this is the definitive performance of the song:
The entire pro-shot video shown is pure-joy. Thanks, Ken. Mark Stricherz

Have always felt WOAD a great and important album for our generation born in the 40s and 50s addressing life’s mortality and memories of love, family and work. Love the use of the Revolver Beatles’ title in “Tomorrow Never Knows” The whole album is a beautiful composition. I shared a few of the songs with my older brother, who is a Beatles’ fan from the beginning. Mark Stricherz.
Wow! Now I’m going to pop in the CD and listen with a different mindset …
The album version is classic!
A beautiful “Tom Joad” version. My mother had this–“Oh, what a beautiful morning, oh, what a beautiful day”– painted in cursive above our kitchen in the 1950’s, 60’s, etc. Mark S.
Let it slip mind how great this tour was–described perfectly. MS
Wow! Gut-wrenching …
I do too, especially when he opens the show that way. It’s a nice jolt of familiarity and unpredictability at the same time.
I love it when he “localizes” his shows, paying homage and saluting the music of a particular town he may be in.
Was at the show in philly. Shocked when they opened with it. Was always an emotional song for me. Loved your take. Keep up the good work. Thank you Ken
Fantastic , it’s probably always been my favourite song on The River, something , always something I couldn’t put my finger on ,I think the pace and the lack of hysteria , just quality .
Your blog is always worth a visit!
Hey! This is cool! Everything’s Alright ….
great,thanks
Never saw it that way, but you make sense. If true, it’s a great song

Thanks again for sharing this one Ken – performed in 1970 and 1971 and that’s it ? Wow – what a gem to hear – appreciated – love the raw nature of this powerful song – Bruce is fine tuning his lyric prowess-

Thank you, Kris, both for the note and for reading! There’s definitely Western Stars material coming at some point. I just don’t know when, because Google randomizer decides what I’m going to write about each day. But with 990 articles left to write and 13 Western Stars songs among them, hopefully I’ll get to write at least one this autumn. 🙂

Ken, I only just discovered this blog, and I’m utterly staggered by the depth of your knowledge and analysis. It’s extremely gratifying to read someone’s thoughts so in parallel with my own about this songwriter/performer’s greatness, and to also gain such incredible knowledge and have collated such a depth of history and recordings. I’m very eager to read daily and can’t wait to share with others. I hope you’ll add Western Stars material soon, too!

Amazing. Ken, you never fail to inform, delight and have Bruce’ astounding history in music to share. As always,
Thank You! Born in the U. S. A.
Thanks for the share!
Oh my goodness, On Top of Old Smokey is pure gold! Thanks for this joyous pick, I never heard before.
This sounds like a song that Adam Sandler would write and then Bruce’s delivery has Sandler’s weird stop and go style. I wonder…
